required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: CyberSenga: Internet-based HIV Prevention in Uganda
clinical_study.official_title: CyberSenga: Harnessing the Power of the Internet to Prevent HIV in Ugandan Youth

lead_sponsor.agency: Center for Innovative Public Health Research

collaborator.agency: Mbarara University of Science and Technology
Internet Solutions for Kids Uganda, Limited

clinical_study.source: Center for Innovative Public Health Research

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators propose to design and test an Internet-based HIV prevention program for adolescents in Uganda.

detailed_description.textblock:
HIV/AIDS is a major contributor to morbidity and mortality in Uganda. Despite aggressive advances in HIV prevention efforts, recent data suggest that HIV prevalence is increasing generally, and HIV knowledge, a direct contributor to behavior, is on the decline among young people specifically as compared to a decade ago.
The Internet is a promising mode of intervention delivery in resource poor-settings because the costs associated with scaling up are minimal; dissemination online is the same if one person or 100,000 people use the program. Just as important, it provides access to important health information in a stigma-free, anonymous atmosphere. Our recent data indicate that 45% of adolescents in Mbarara, Uganda have used the Internet, 78% of whom went online at least once in the previous week. Eighty-one percent of respondents in the same survey indicated they would go to an HIV prevention web site if it existed. Based upon these data, we propose to develop a culturally appropriate, Internet-based HIV prevention program designed specifically for Ugandan adolescents between the ages of 12 and 18 years. Our specific aims are as follows:
Specific Aim 1: Design a 6-hour, Internet-based HIV prevention program for adolescents. Content will be culturally tailored to the HIV preventive information, motivation, and behavioral skills needs of Ugandan adolescents.
Specific Aim 2: Test the intervention in a randomized controlled trial (n=500) among adolescents attending grades Secondary 1-4 (similar to US high school grades 8th - 11th) at day schools in Mbarara.
This project has the potential to develop low-cost and salable interventions to HIV transmission risk behaviors among adolescents in Uganda.

primary_outcome.measure: Sex Without a Condom as Assessed by Self-report
primary_outcome.description: Unprotected sex (i.e., vaginal or anal sex without a condom) in the past three months
Not having had vaginal or anal sex in the past three months

secondary_outcome.description: Sexual abstinence (i.e., not having vaginal or anal sex) in the past 90 days
Ever had vaginal or anal sex without a condom in the past 90 days

arm_group.description: 6-module HIV prevention program tailored for adolescents in Uganda
"treatment as usual" - the sexual health education adolescents currently receive in secondary school

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Enrollment in grades Secondary 1 through 4 at a partner secondary school
- Having used a computer or the Internet at least once in the past year
- Not having been part of the intervention development activities
- Caregiver informed permission and adolescent informed assent
Exclusion Criteria:

facility.name: Internet Solutions for Kids Uganda, Limited

Ybarra ML, Biringi R, Prescott T, Bull SS. Usability and navigability of an HIV/AIDS internet intervention for adolescents in a resource-limited setting. Comput Inform Nurs. 2012 Nov;30(11):587-95; quiz 596-7. doi: 10.1097/NXN.0b013e318266cb0e.

Katz IT, Ybarra ML, Wyatt MA, Kiwanuka JP, Bangsberg DR, Ware NC. Socio-cultural and economic antecedents of adolescent sexual decision-making and HIV-risk in rural Uganda. AIDS Care. 2013;25(2):258-64. doi: 10.1080/09540121.2012.701718. Epub 2012 Jul 27.

Ybarra ML, Bull SS, Kiwanuka J, Bangsberg DR, Korchmaros J. Prevalence rates of sexual coercion victimization and perpetration among Uganda adolescents. AIDS Care. 2012;24(11):1392-400. doi: 10.1080/09540121.2011.648604. Epub 2012 Feb 2.

Ybarra ML, Emenyonu N, Nansera D, Kiwanuka J, Bangsberg DR. Health information seeking among Mbararan adolescents: results from the Uganda Media and You survey. Health Educ Res. 2008 Apr;23(2):249-58. Epub 2007 Jul 16.

results_reference.citation: Ybarra ML, Korchmaros JD, Prescott TL, Birungi R. A Randomized Controlled Trial to Increase HIV Preventive Information, Motivation, and Behavioral Skills in Ugandan Adolescents. Ann Behav Med. 2015 Jun;49(3):473-85. doi: 10.1007/s12160-014-9673-0.

Ybarra ML, Bull SS, Prescott TL, Birungi R. Acceptability and feasibility of CyberSenga: an Internet-based HIV-prevention program for adolescents in Mbarara, Uganda. AIDS Care. 2014 Apr;26(4):441-7. doi: 10.1080/09540121.2013.841837. Epub 2013 Oct 4.

Adolescent abstinence and unprotected sex in CyberSenga, an Internet-based HIV prevention program: randomized clinical trial of efficacy. study_doc.doc_comment: All study documents (consent form, surveys, etc) are available for free download at the study site

participant_flow.recruitment_details: We aimed to screen all 382 female students enrolled in the two mixed-sex schools and 772 of the 2,264 male students enrolled across the four schools to identify 400 eligible youth. Many youth were out of school trying to secure school fees or had changed schools. As a result, 740 of the youth were screened, 416 of whom were eligible (56%).

measure.title: Ever known someone who died from AIDS
Tired of hearing about HIV prevention information
Above average change of getting HIV
measure.description: Self-appraisal of one's likelihood of getting HIV

measure.title: Beliefs supportive of HIV Stigma
measure.description: This measure has a range from 0 to 4 with higher scores reflecting greater HIV stigma

measure.title: Ever been a victim of teen dating violence
Ever been a perpetrator of teen dating violence
Beliefs consistent with female empowerment in relationships
measure.description: This measure has scores that can range from 2 to 10 with higher scores being higher in these beliefs

measure.title: Bright future somewhat/very unlikely
measure.description: subject chose between somewhat likely and very likely

measure.title: The Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support : Social support from "special person"
measure.description: This measure has scores possibly ranging form 1 to 20 with higher scores reflecting more support

measure.title: The Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support: Social support from family
measure.description: This measure has scores possibly ranging form 1 to 20 with higher scores reflecting more support

measure.title: Information
measure.description: 80% or more answers about HIV correct

measure.title: Motivation: Attitudes towards HIV preventive acts
measure.description: This measure has scores possibly ranging form 1 to 5 with higher scores reflecting more motivation

measure.title: Motivation: Subjective norms regarding HIV preventive acts
measure.description: This measure has scores possibly ranging form 1 to 5 with higher scores reflecting more motivation

measure.title: Motivation: Behavioral intentions for HIV prevention
measure.description: This measure has scores possibly ranging form 1 to 5 with higher scores reflecting more motivation

measure.title: Behavioral Skills
measure.description: This measure has scores possibly ranging form 1 to 5 with higher scores reflecting more skills

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data were collected through the study period (i.e., from baseline to 6 month follow-up).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Sexual activity in adolescence is a stigmatized behavior in Uganda, especially for females. Youth may have under-reported their sexual experiences, which in the intervention group would have led to them being triaged to the incorrect content.

point_of_contact.organization: Center for Innovative Public Health Reserch
